titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Liberty Hall collection, 1971-2016 MS 658
titlestmt.author: Norie Guthrie

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored off-site at the Library Service Center. Please request this material via woodson@rice.edu or call 713-348-2586.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-10-04 17:42:40 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.abstract: This collection mainly consists of memorabilia and ephemera from the music venue Liberty Hall.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Liberty Hall was a music venue located in downtown Houston, Texas from 1971 to 1978. It was originally owned and operated by Michael Condray, Lynda Herrera, and Ryan Trimble. Hosting a wide variety of performers, including Bruce Springsteen, ZZ Top, The Velvet Underground, The Ramones, Lightnin' Hopkins, Big Mama Thornton, and many more, it was known for its low admittance prices of sometimes only two dollars for nationally known entertainers.

Before Liberty Hall, Condray and George Banks, the future graphic illustrator of Liberty Hall posters, opened Jubilee Hall which became the Family Hand, a restaurant and entertainment venue. The restaurant was known for its red beans and rice, prepared by Thera Neumann, the African-American female chef. When Condray began looking for a new location to open with Herrera and Trimble, Neumann found the building that would become Liberty Hall. The building was originally a church built in the 1940s and later became the American Legion Post 391. On March 4, 1971, it opened as Liberty Hall.

Besides the many musicians that performed at Liberty Hall, the venue hosted plays and comedy performances. Cheech and Chong performed for a completely sold out four-night stand for two dollars a ticket. Cheech and Chong credit Liberty Hall for their success. Liberty Hall also hosted rock opera director C. C. Courtney's play "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" from March 23 to April 22, 1972. At the time, it was the longest running play in the history of Houston.

In 1974, Herrera left Liberty Hall with Condray following in 1975. Trimble stayed on until the venue closed in 1978. The building that was once Liberty Hall was soon demolished after its closing. Today, a parking lot near the Toyota Center sits where Liberty Hall once was.
Text borrowed from the "Liberty Hall (Houston, Texas)" Wikipedia page written by Woodson staff member Claire Weddle.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the photographs, news clippings, posters, realia and a scrapbook documenting the history of the music venue Liberty Hall. Materials from co-owner Michael Condray's later music venture Showbar is also included.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.
Stored offsite at the Library Service Center and require 24-hour notice for retrieval. Please contact the Woodson Research Center at 713-348-2586 or woodson@rice.edu for more information.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional materials are expected for this collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Gerry Ebel, Lynda Herrera, Ryan Trimble, and Bruce Bryant on behalf of Richard "Ace" Brooks in 2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Liberty Hall collection, 1971-2016, MS 658, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from this material must be obtained from the Woodson Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The items in this file consist of images taken at Mike Condray's Memorial at Ovations Club by a Woodson staff member. These are jpg files.

did.unittitle: Bruce Springsteen at Liberty Hall (2 CDs)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Tracks include: "Soundcheck: Satin Doll - Beer Barrel Polka"; "Satin Doll"; "Does This Bus Stop at 82nd Street?"; "Growin' Up"; "Mary Queen of Arkansas"; "Wild Billy's Circus Story"; "Sentimental Journey"; "The Fever"; "Something You Got - Heat Wave"; Springsteen interview recorded the day before the band's appearance at the station. Bruce Springsteen - guitar, lead vocals; Danny Federici - accordian; Clarence Clemons - saxophone; Garry Tallent - tuba

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Tracks include: "Down Drinking at the Bar"; "I Am the Way (New York Town)"; "Have You Ever Been to Pittsburgh?"; "New Paint"; "Nocturnal Stumblebutt"; "Bell Bottom Pants"; "Clockwork Chartreuse"; "Liza"; "A.M. World"; "Muse Blues"; "Be Careful There's a Baby in th House"; "Unrequited to the Nth Degree"; "Lullabye"; "The You Hurt Me Mantra"; "The Man Who Couldn't Cry"; "Medley: I Know I'm Unhappy - Suicice Song". Digitized from the KPFT master reel

did.unittitle: Doug Sahm and the Tex Mex Band live

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Tracks include: "Papa Ain't Salty"; "Texas Tornados"; "Rain Rain"; "At the Crossroads"; "Stormy Monday"; "Georgia on My Mind"; "Wasted Days and Wasted Nights"; "San Antone (Is Anybody Going to). Performers: Doug Sahm - vocals, guitar, piano; Augie Meyer - organ and piano; Link Davis, Jr. - vocals, alto saxophone, tenor saxophone, baritone saxophone, piano, organ; Doug Clifford - drums; Stu Cook - bass guitar. Originally played on KPFT Radio, later reboradcast by VPRO Radio, 1979-02-02

did.unittitle: Townes Van Zandt live at Liberty Hall - KPFT (10.5" reel-to-reel audio)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s.
